subject: apgov
title: Gibbons v. Ogden
quickTake: Only Congress can regulate interstate commerce, including navigation.
corePrompt: Can New York grant a monopoly that blocks a federally licensed operator from running steamboats between states?
answerText: The Commerce Clause gives Congress power over interstate commerce, and federal licensing overrides conflicting state laws.
facts: New York granted an exclusive steamboat operating right to Ogden.
Gibbons operated competing steamboats using a federal coastal license.
Ogden sued to stop Gibbons under the New York monopoly.
reasoning: Commerce includes navigation when it crosses state lines.
When Congress acts within its commerce power, conflicting state restrictions are invalid.
The decision favors a single national market over state barriers.
precedent: Expanded the scope of the Commerce Clause.
Limited state-created economic barriers that conflict with federal authority.

terms.definition: Gives Congress power to regulate commerce among the states.
Economic activity that crosses state lines or affects trade between states.

whyExam: Key case for understanding the Commerce Clause and federal supremacy.
Often paired with McCulloch to show early strengthening of national power.
whyReal: Helped create consistent rules for trade across states.
Cited in later debates about federal regulation of the economy.
leadsTo: Later Commerce Clause cases that test the limits of federal regulation
connectsBack: McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) for national supremacy over conflicting state action
